articles.headline: India’s Tax Plan Troubles Foreign Investors
articles.snippet: Some international investors are delaying investments in India, a sign of concern over a raft of new taxes proposed by the government.
articles.abstract: Some international investors are delaying investments in India, a sign of concern over a raft of new taxes proposed by the government.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — Just two months ago, worried about their slowing economy, Indian officials were promising to promote policies to make the country more hospitable to foreign investment.

articles.headline: In Spain, Women Enslaved by a Boom in Brothel Tourism
articles.snippet: While the rest of Spain’s economy struggles, prostitution — almost all of it involving the ruthless trafficking of foreign women — is exploding into public view.
articles.abstract: While the rest of Spain’s economy struggles, prostitution — almost all of it involving the ruthless trafficking of foreign women — is exploding into public view.
articles.lead_paragraph: LA JONQUERA, Spain — She had expected a job in a hotel. But when Valentina arrived here two months ago from Romania, the man who helped her get here — a man she had considered her boyfriend — made it clear that the job was on the side of the road.

articles.headline: Swatting Down Start-Ups That Help Consumers
articles.snippet: AutoSlash, a car rental site that searches for the best rates, has earned the enmity of Hertz, Enterprise and other rental giants. Airlines haven’t been much warmer to services that help passengers.
articles.abstract: AutoSlash, a car rental site that searches for the best rates, has earned the enmity of Hertz, Enterprise and other rental giants. Airlines haven’t been much warmer to services that help passengers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Back in February, I dived deeply into the workings of AutoSlash, a little company making big waves in the world of car rentals.

articles.headline: Some Dreary Forecasts From Recovery Skeptics
articles.snippet: A group of economists called permabears offer what they say are more realistic assessments of the economy and the tepid pace of the recovery.
articles.abstract: A group of economists called permabears offer what they say are more realistic assessments of the economy and the tepid pace of the recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When a lackluster jobs report came in on Friday morning, some economists, investors and forecasters were hardly surprised.

articles.headline: Pressed From All Sides, Toys ‘R’ Us Fights to Reinvent Itself
articles.snippet: The last of the big toy stores struggles to revamp its business as sales decline, management defects, and debt and competition mount.
articles.abstract: The last of the big toy stores struggles to revamp its business as sales decline, management defects, and debt and competition mount.
articles.lead_paragraph: For nearly two years, Toys “R” Us has waited for the right moment to take itself public.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Clifford and Peter Lattman

articles.headline: Troubling Flaws in a Heart Device Shake Implant Makers
articles.snippet: A problem with wires in a defibrillator is the industry’s third highly visible safety episode in seven years, inviting discussion of a greater role for the F.D.A.
articles.abstract: A problem with wires in a defibrillator is the industry’s third highly visible safety episode in seven years, inviting discussion of a greater role for the F.D.A.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last October, a high school football coach named Greg Jessee was standing on the sidelines watching his son play when he felt a jolt to his chest. The heart defibrillator implanted in him five years earlier was firing wildly. The next jolt made him double up. The one after that knocked him unconscious.
articles.byline: By Barry Meier and Katie Thomas

articles.headline: Limits on Lobbyists as Hosts? Simply Unworkable, They Say
articles.snippet: The Obama administration would prevent federal workers from attending seminars, receptions and social gatherings for free, which lobbyists have denounced as excessive.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration would prevent federal workers from attending seminars, receptions and social gatherings for free, which lobbyists have denounced as excessive.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Tough new limits proposed on the way special interests could court executive branch officials have prompted a fierce counterattack from lobbyists who fear they will end a cherished Washington ritual: hosting federal workers at events like conferences, cocktail parties, galas and movie screenings.

articles.headline: China Buys Inroads in the Caribbean, Catching U.S. Notice
articles.snippet: China’s economic might has rolled up to America’s doorstep, with loans from state banks, investments by companies and outright gifts from the government.
articles.abstract: China’s economic might has rolled up to America’s doorstep, with loans from state banks, investments by companies and outright gifts from the government.
articles.lead_paragraph: NASSAU, the Bahamas — A brand new $35 million stadium opened here in the Bahamas a few weeks ago, a gift from the Chinese government.

articles.headline: In Executive Pay, a Rich Game of Thrones
articles.snippet: Although the growth in C.E.O. compensation slowed last year, the pay numbers are still eye-popping.
articles.abstract: Although the growth in C.E.O. compensation slowed last year, the pay numbers are still eye-popping.
articles.lead_paragraph: IS any C.E.O. worth $1 million a day?

articles.headline: When Shareholders Make Their Voices Heard
articles.snippet: This year, the people who actually own public companies are gaining some influence over corporate executive pay practices, via say-on-pay votes.
articles.abstract: This year, the people who actually own public companies are gaining some influence over corporate executive pay practices, via say-on-pay votes.
articles.lead_paragraph: IN spring, a shareholder’s fancy turns to thoughts of pay.

articles.headline: Spam Invades a Last Refuge, the Cellphone
articles.snippet: Cellphone customers received roughly 4.5 billion spam texts last year, twice as many as in 2009, and remedies to the growing menace are few.
articles.abstract: Cellphone customers received roughly 4.5 billion spam texts last year, twice as many as in 2009, and remedies to the growing menace are few.
articles.lead_paragraph: Text message spam has started waking Bob Dunnell in the middle of the night, promising cheap mortgages, credit cards and drugs. Some messages offer gift cards to, say, Walmart, if he clicks on a Web site and enters his Social Security number.

articles.headline: U.S. Defines Its Demands for New Round of Talks With Iran
articles.snippet: The Obama administration and its allies plan to call for the immediate closing and ultimate dismantling of a recently completed nuclear facility, American and European diplomats say.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration and its allies plan to call for the immediate closing and ultimate dismantling of a recently completed nuclear facility, American and European diplomats say.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration and its European allies plan to open new negotiations with Iran by demanding the immediate closing and ultimate dismantling of a recently completed nuclear facility deep under a mountain, according to American and European diplomats.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: Tuna Again? In Fault-Finding England, It’s a Cause for Divorce
articles.snippet: Excessive servings of tuna casserole is just one example of marital distress from the divorce dockets of England, which does not have no-fault divorce.
articles.abstract: Excessive servings of tuna casserole is just one example of marital distress from the divorce dockets of England, which does not have no-fault divorce.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — In her 30-odd years as a divorce lawyer, Vanessa Lloyd Platt has heard it all. The woman who sued for divorce because her husband insisted she dress in a Klingon costume and speak to him in Klingon. The man who declared that his wife had maliciously and repeatedly served him his least favorite dish, tuna casserole.

articles.headline: Welfare Limits Left Poor Adrift as Recession Hit
articles.snippet: Some recipients of aid under the Clinton-era Temporary Assistance for Needy Families program have taken desperate measures to make ends meet.
articles.abstract: Some recipients of aid under the Clinton-era Temporary Assistance for Needy Families program have taken desperate measures to make ends meet.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Perhaps no law in the past generation has drawn more praise than the drive to “end welfare as we know it,” which joined the late-’90s economic boom to send caseloads plunging, employment rates rising and officials of both parties hailing the virtues of tough love.

articles.headline: A Friendship Dating to 1976 Resonates in 2012
articles.snippet: The friendship between Mitt Romney and Benjamin Netanyahu, little known to outsiders, is now rich with political intrigue.
articles.abstract: The friendship between Mitt Romney and Benjamin Netanyahu, little known to outsiders, is now rich with political intrigue.
articles.lead_paragraph: The two young men had woefully little in common: one was a wealthy Mormon from Michigan, the other a middle-class Jew from Israel.

articles.headline: U.S. Transfers Control of Night Raids to Afghanistan
articles.snippet: An agreement on raids that are deeply unpopular in Afghanistan would give legal oversight to Afghan forces, putting American troops in a supporting role.
articles.abstract: An agreement on raids that are deeply unpopular in Afghanistan would give legal oversight to Afghan forces, putting American troops in a supporting role.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Accelerating the transition of military responsibility to the Afghan government, the United States agreed Sunday to hand control of special operations missions to Afghan forces, including night raids, relegating American troops to a supporting role and bringing the raids under Afghan judicial authority.

articles.headline: Mike Wallace, CBS Pioneer of ‘60 Minutes,’ Dies at 93
articles.snippet: A reporter with the presence of a performer, Mr. Wallace went head-to-head with chiefs of state, celebrities and con artists for more than 50 years.
articles.abstract: A reporter with the presence of a performer, Mr. Wallace went head-to-head with chiefs of state, celebrities and con artists for more than 50 years.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mike Wallace, the CBS reporter who became one of America’s best-known broadcast journalists as an interrogator of the famous and infamous on “60 Minutes,” died on Saturday. He was 93.

articles.headline: In Europe, Unease Over Bank Debt
articles.snippet: While bond purchases pushed down borrowing costs and helped Spain and Italy avoid a Greek-style bailout from the euro zone, they once again have enmeshed the banks in their debt woes.
articles.abstract: While bond purchases pushed down borrowing costs and helped Spain and Italy avoid a Greek-style bailout from the euro zone, they once again have enmeshed the banks in their debt woes.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Only a few months ago, banks around the world were scrambling to sell piles of European government bonds that had lost value as the Continent’s sovereign debt crisis flared.

articles.headline: Measuring Up Citigroup and Bank of America
articles.snippet: Bank of America and Citigroup have plenty in common, and when bank earnings are revealed in the coming weeks, investors will be watching to see how the two match up.
articles.abstract: Bank of America and Citigroup have plenty in common, and when bank earnings are revealed in the coming weeks, investors will be watching to see how the two match up.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bank of America used to be the stock Wall Street loved to hate. Citigroup, on the other hand, was supposed to be the troubled bank that had finally gotten its act together.

articles.headline: Supremacy in Jeopardy for ‘Today’
articles.snippet: “Good Morning America” is coming up fast in the ratings behind the consistently top-rated “Today” show.
articles.abstract: “Good Morning America” is coming up fast in the ratings behind the consistently top-rated “Today” show.
articles.lead_paragraph: These days, the effervescent smiles on the “Today” show, America’s most popular morning television companion, are concealing anxiety.
articles.byline: By Brian Stelter and Bill Carter

articles.headline: Newspaper Barons Resurface
articles.snippet: Newspapers may be short on profits, but they have become a new form of ostentation for some very wealthy people. Their motives? Let’s be optimistic.
articles.abstract: Newspapers may be short on profits, but they have become a new form of ostentation for some very wealthy people. Their motives? Let’s be optimistic.
articles.lead_paragraph: Is there anything more forlorn than the American metropolitan newspaper? First readers began deserting in droves, then the advertisers followed. Family owners headed for the exits and then hedge funds and other financial players scooped up newspapers thinking they were buying at the bottom of the market. Greater fools came and went, each saying they could cut their way to former glory and renewed profitability. They got a haircut instead.

articles.headline: Apps Take Positions in the Topps Baseball Lineup
articles.snippet: The Topps Company, the leading baseball card manufacturer, is trying to breathe digital life into a once-cherished hobby with apps aimed at a techcentric youth market.
articles.abstract: The Topps Company, the leading baseball card manufacturer, is trying to breathe digital life into a once-cherished hobby with apps aimed at a techcentric youth market.
articles.lead_paragraph: This baseball season, one of the game’s most beloved and bygone traditions will try for a comeback: the baseball card.

articles.headline: Tightening the Lid on Pain Prescriptions
articles.snippet: Experts say that doctors, despite the dangers, often keep patients on high-strength painkillers known as opioids for years without properly checking to see if their conditions improve.
articles.abstract: Experts say that doctors, despite the dangers, often keep patients on high-strength painkillers known as opioids for years without properly checking to see if their conditions improve.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — It was the type of conversation that Dr. Claire Trescott dreads: telling physicians that they are not cutting it.

articles.headline: A Ballooning Megabyte Budget
articles.snippet: With smartphones, people are confronting the task of calculating their data usage to avoid unexpected fees.
articles.abstract: With smartphones, people are confronting the task of calculating their data usage to avoid unexpected fees.
articles.lead_paragraph: Everyone knows how long a minute is. And your cellphone carrier keeps close tabs on how many you have used this month. Now, in the smartphone era, more people are being forced to think about how many megabytes of data they are using.

articles.headline: Federal Funds to Train the Jobless Are Drying Up
articles.snippet: Money for the primary training program for dislocated workers is 18 percent lower than it was in 2006, even though there are six million more people looking for work now.
articles.abstract: Money for the primary training program for dislocated workers is 18 percent lower than it was in 2006, even though there are six million more people looking for work now.
articles.lead_paragraph: With the economy slowly reviving, an executive from Atlas Van Lines recently visited Louisville, Ky., with good news: the company wanted to hire more than 100 truck drivers ahead of the summer moving season.

articles.headline: ‘Super PAC,’ Eyeing General Election, Aims Blitz at Obama
articles.snippet: Amid a growing perception that Mitt Romney will be the party’s nominee, the biggest of the Republican “super PACs” is set to begin its first major anti-Obama advertising campaign.
articles.abstract: Amid a growing perception that Mitt Romney will be the party’s nominee, the biggest of the Republican “super PACs” is set to begin its first major anti-Obama advertising campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: American Crossroads, the biggest of the Republican “super PACs,” is planning to begin its first major anti-Obama advertising blitz of the year, a moment the Obama re-election campaign has been girding for and another sign that the general election is starting in earnest.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Jeff Zeleny
